text: Many of these institutions have vast social and political power, and are hugely influential on many nation's laws (including our own). It's bizarre to watch folks criticize, say, the trans ban in the US military and then attend a church that treats LGBT people as second class.

text: This is increasingly a point of frustration for me. Americans like to treat religion like it's different, like it's fine if the religious institutions you support are absolutely bigoted - discriminating against women and LGBT people in ways you would never accept anywhere else.

text: And of course a lot of this results from extreme inequality, plus exploitation of workers & no support for parents. If you work a minimum wage job with no time off and you have rent to pay & kids to feed, forget paying for test prep. Where's even the time to read aloud?
author: JillFilipovic

text: It also wouldn't be a terrible idea for colleges to ask students to disclose things like test prep classes or tutoring. Not as a "points off" thing, but just to help admissions offices figure out what resources students were operating with.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It would mean real racial integration of schools - something white liberal parents of course say they support, but that many balk at when it means kids of color (and black kids in particular) coming to "their" school and "their" school district.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So what would evening the educational playing field entail? First and foremost, it would mean fair and generous funding of public schools - funding based on student numbers and need, not on local property values.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If we want an education system that more closely resembles a meritocracy, we have to do more than just prosecute criminal parents. We have to even the playing field - which really freaks a lot of people out.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Even something as simple as getting extra time to take a test is skewed toward the wealthy and privileged. Some students DO in fact need extra time for test-taking. But to get it, you often have to have a parent who is savvy enough to advocate for you (and has the time to do so).
author: JillFilipovic

text: That isn't to cast blame on parents who use (legal) means to advantage their child (the ones who use illegal means should indeed be in big trouble). It is to say that the entire system is skewed and is not about "merit," which is how individuals justify truly egregious acts.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Yup. And legacy is just the tip of the iceberg. What these parents did was blatant, but so many others use their immense resources to buy all kinds of advantages for their children, from tuition at elite high schools to pricey test prep to expensive extracurriculars.

text: I say this as someone who, a decade or so ago, was really attracted to the idea of clinic defense, because it sounded necessary and badass, and more direct than "vote pro-choice." And then I talked to folks who actually work at clinics and live this stuff every day.

text: Basically, this is activism as self-indulgent performance. It doesn't actually help women. If you want to help women get into clinics safely, I encourage you to sign up to be an escort at your local clinic. If you want to support abortion access, donate to an abortion fund.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Read this thread. "Clinic defenders" mean well, but only add to chaos & strife outside of clinics - NOT what women just trying to get medical care at a vulnerable time need. There's a difference between clinic defenders and clinic escorts. Want to help? Donate to an abortion fund

text: In any sane country, politicians across the political spectrum would object to this overt self-dealing and the ensuing scandal would be enough to remove the leader from office.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And to be clear, Pelosi didn’t say there shouldn’t be an investigation. But she says impeachment should only happen if it’s bipartisan - which shouldn’t be the answer. And being so unwilling to be “divisive” does not bode well for a thorough investigation, which will also divide.
author: JillFilipovic

text: But taking what might be an appropriate remedy off the table because it’s “divisive” is not the answer. And it’s ceding what is frankly a moral and ethical obligation to uphold the constitution and protect American democracy.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Shying away from a thorough and proper investigation because it’s “divisive” puts petty politics and power before country, and before the obligation to protect American democracy. Is impeachment appropriate? At the very least Congress needs to engage in a full investigation.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Impeachment is serious business and shouldn’t be entered into lightly. But a man is running the executive branch like it’s an organized criminal enterprise, solicited foreign interference in American elections, and uses the office to enrich his family. We can’t ignore &allow that
author: JillFilipovic

text: I agree, and I do not want additional limits on immigration - I want far fewer limits on immigration. The question is, which limits? I understand many folks will say "no limits at all." That is not going to happen at this point in time. So - which do we prioritize lifting?
author: JillFilipovic

text: I agree! But how we do that is called “immigration policy.”
author: JillFilipovic

text: It has nothing to do with whether I think they’re intellectually weighty. It has to do with whether they are influential. And I think it’s hard to deny that they aren’t influential and very real.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think Trump’s policies are absolute shit. I think they are racist. I also recognize that they are our current reality, and if we don’t substantively challenge them and put forward better ideas, including imperfect short-term fixes, we are in trouble.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Does that reflect my deepest held values? No. Does it reflect what I think is the best thing for lots of vulnerable people given the shit reality we are in? Yes.
author: JillFilipovic

text: As you can see if you read my thread, I would prefer every country in the world have open borders. I also think politically, in the US at this moment, it’s not going to happen. So I want an immigration policy that lets in as many people as is feasible, prioritizing refugees.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Because I think at this point in time open borders is a political nonstarter. I think it’s strategically smarter and more effective to fight right now for more liberalized immigration policies that let far more people in and prioritize refugees.
author: JillFilipovic

text: “Frum is a racist whose immigration policy suggestions are substantively the same as Trump’s” is fine if the goal is simply to say that he’s wrong and bad. It doesn’t do much to move the immigration conversation forward or offer a better plan than simply being against Trump.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It should be! Except that this story is on the cover of the Atlantic, so that horse is out of the barn and I’m not sure ignoring it is super smart.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Basically, we ignore influential people and ideas with whom we don’t agree at our peril. Immigration policy is hugely important, and at the moment, millions of vulnerable people suffer because of ours.
author: JillFilipovic

text: As I said in the very first tweet, Frum is wrong in a whole host of ways. But his ideas, published in an influential magazine, are indeed intended to influence policy-makers. Which is why I think it’s worth engaging them and challenging them and putting better ideas forward.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You don’t need to engage with Frum himself. But like it or not, the ideas he puts forward in a piece published in an influential magazine are going to have some sway. You can ignore them, but I think it’s better to challenge them, engage them, and offer better solutions.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Who and how many is the basis of every immigration policy. Maybe the answer is no immigration policy at all. But I think that’s going to be a very hard sell right now. And so what do we (and a whole lot of refugees and people who want to immigrate) do in the meantime?
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is extremely disingenuous. I said clearly that I don’t agree with Frum. But I do think we need to engage on immigration. And if the left just says “anything other than open borders is bad”- and doesn’t put forward any other policy ideas, we are going to lose.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Feel free to read my mentions.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If I had my way borders would be a thing of the past. In this particular political reality, I would like an immigration policy that let in many many times the number of refugees we’ve historically let in, as a starting point.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Instead a lot of the ground gets ceded to the right, because suggesting anything short of open borders is now seen as capitulating. I think that’s a recipe for really bad outcomes for huge numbers of would-be immigrants. Do I wish this reality was different? Yes. Is it? No.
author: JillFilipovic

text: From my view, the right to move is fundamental, and laws restricting migration are fundamentally immoral. But unfortunately, in this world, immigration laws are a reality, and if we want more progressive ones, we need to make that case.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It is extremely rich that you think you know anything about my personal financial status! And as you can see from the rest of my thread, I am a big proponent of immigration and in fact ideologically support open borders.
author: JillFilipovic

text: From my view, we should be prioritizing refugees first and foremost. I understand the answer for the left on twitter is “open borders,” and I think it’s important to make that case, but in the shorter term it can’t be “anything short of open borders isn’t worth supporting.”
author: JillFilipovic

text: To be clear I’m not saying that in an ideal world “who / how many” would be the question. But in THIS world, with this American political landscape, it is.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Immigration policy is a tough one for the left. In the Trump era it’s frankly gotten easier because his policies are so racist and draconian it’s easy to be against them and support immigration more broadly. But a good comprehensive progressive immigration plan? I haven’t seen it
author: JillFilipovic

text: Putting aside the headline, this @davidfrum piece is worth reading and engaging. I think he’s wrong from approximately 16,009 different angles, but it’s worth debating his conclusions. One good point: “immigration: yes/no” is not the question, but “how / who / how many?” is.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I realize Frum says this ideal was “never fully realized.” But I’m not sure “every worker” was ever the ideal. Highlighting this not because it undermines his piece - it doesn’t - but to point out that certain assumptions continue to shape our national narratives away from truth.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So um, in addition to a lot of other problems with this, America was in fact built, physically, by an enormous number of people who were forced into unpaid labor. They couldn’t vote. And one of our two political parties continues to try to block their descendants from voting.

text: Such horrible news.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Mandatory vaccines are covered by programs for the indigent. The problem isn’t parents being too poor to afford vaccines. The problem is parents choosing not to vaccinate.
author: JillFilipovic

text: All of this - anti-vaxxers, the hardcore homeschooling crowd that opposes any oversight of, requirements to, or standardization of at-home education  - stems from this same idea that children are their parents’ property, not individuals with basic rights.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And look, in my ideal universe, children would have rights as individuals and not just extensions of their parents - including a right to health care and a right to education. Require vaccinations for public school; regulate homeschooling & make sure kids kept home are safe.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Well, the other option is potentially depriving other children of health and life. And in my ideal universe homeschooling and private schooling would be much more regulated to ensure every child gets a decent education.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway, these cases make me absolutely insane, the parents should possibly face criminal neglect charges (or should be sued by an appointed guardian for this child), and at the very least states should not be allowing public school attendance unless a child is vaccinated.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And we should not have a health care system that would allow patients (or their parents / guardians) to be charged more for extreme negligence. But man do my worst impulses say that I wish the parents had to pay out of pocket for 100% of the care for a problem they created.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Stories like this make me so viscerally angry and these parents are putting there child at such risk that I want to say that Child Protective Services should intervene, but that’s obviously a very extreme reaction, and breaking up families should be an extreme last resort.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s so tough to come up with the best solution to this. Obviously public schools should require vaccination, with exceptions only for health (i.e., an immunocompromised child). But not every kid is in public school, and plenty of parents put their kids at risk.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s true. But psychologically I just can’t take it! Seeing outside pants in my bed,or foods that crumb, or suitcases or anything dirty just stresses me out.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sit on the subway for one!
author: JillFilipovic

text: Never ceases to amaze me that I get better cell service in rural central Kenya than on Bedford Ave in central Williamsburg.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I allow my (indoor) cats to sleep in my bed.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This might be the #1 source of conflict in my household, which has only recently been partly solved by the gift of several pairs of soft pants that make “inside pants” a more tempting option. But the struggle is real. And suitcases on the bed?!?!
author: JillFilipovic

text: Had the pleasure of hearing Nanjala speak last week about digital colonialism, the emergent power of the Kenyan feminist Internet, and the problem with relying on tech to fix the problems of the state. Her work is necessary, nuanced complex. Buy her book! https://www.amazon.com/Digital-Democracy-Analogue-Politics-Transforming/dp/1786994313/ref=nodl_ …
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is a very important case and great reporting. Just a minor quibble because the language does matter here: a six-week-old pregnancy involves an embryo, not a fetus.
author: JillFilipovic

text: The case in Alabama where a man is suing a clinic because he's mad that his teenage ex girlfriend had an abortion brings into such clear focus the goal of the #prolife movement: To put women's futures, and our very bodies, in the hands of controlling men.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Ok getting off of a train, but tweet me the stories about women worldwide that you think could use more attention / that illustrate the tremendous struggles women continue to face / that show how women in every community and country are fighting back and I'll add them.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Women are a minority in nearly every parliament in the world (with just three exceptions). The nation with the highest proportion of women in Parliament is Rwanda, where there are gender quotas and a dictator means Parliament isn't quite so important. https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/sg.gen.parl.zs?year_high_desc=true …
author: JillFilipovic

text: According to @AP, "Thousands of Indian women are killed — often doused in gasoline and burned to death — every year because the groom or his family feel the dowry she brought to the wedding was inadequate."
author: JillFilipovic

text: More than 200 million women would like contraception to plan their families, but can't get it. Lack of contraception access means worse health outcomes for mothers & babies, higher rates of maternal & infant mortality, and lower education rates for girls.
author: JillFilipovic

text: There are a great many countries where even emergency contraception is outlawed. This includes popular tourism destinations like Costa Rica, St. Kitts & Nevis, Montenegro, the UAE.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_contraceptive_availability_by_country …
author: JillFilipovic

text: Child marriage happens in the US, too - and perhaps more shockingly, efforts to end it are systematically opposed by "family values" conservatives. Some laws have a pregnancy loophole - you can marry a kid if you get her pregnant. https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/kentucky-child-marriage-ban-delayed-vote-conservative-group-opposition-lawmakers-us-a8240121.html …
author: JillFilipovic

text: Every year, 12 million girls are married before they turn 18. One in 5 girls worldwide is married as a child. The places where more than 50% of girls marry as children (before 18): Niger, CAR, Chad, Bangladesh, South Sudan, Mali, Guinea, and Burkina Faso.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Around the world, some 1 billion women lack protection from domestic violence.
author: JillFilipovic

text: In Russia, the right wing and its benefactors in the Russian Orthodox Church successfully pushed to largely decriminalize domestic violence. Now, feminists face state censure and jail time, but men who try to kill their wives don't:
author: JillFilipovic

text: The Global Gag Rule, which wreaked havoc on women's health across the developing world, has now come to the US, infringing on the 1st Amendment rights and ethical obligations of providers to tell patients the full range of their health care options.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Across the world, health providers who receive US $$ are currently barred from providing abortions with their own non-US money, advocating for abortion rights in their own countries, or even referring patients who want abortions to a different provider.
author: JillFilipovic

text: In Kenya, new mothers who can't pay their hospital bills after birth are routinely locked inside, essentially imprisoned in what should be a healthcare facility:
author: JillFilipovic

text: In Saudi Arabia, women live under the guardianship of male relatives (including their own sons), who control nearly every aspect of their lives. Women who advocate for their own rights have been jailed and allegedly tortured.
author: JillFilipovic

text: In Alabama, a judge has granted legal status to a no-longer-in-existence embryo after a man who allegedly coerced his 16-year-old girlfriend into sex sued the clinic that provided her abortion. He is suing for the right of men to control women's bodies:
author: JillFilipovic

text: Happy International Women's Day! Around the world, women still face systematic discrimination, abuse, and violence. A few stories and issues worth paying attention to:
author: JillFilipovic

text: YES. I've been experimenting with intermittent fasting as well, and cutting out breakfast was easy because (1) I'm not hungry in the morning, and (2) it was my most repetitive and boring meal of the week. I dedicate significant time thinking about what I want to try & planning it
author: JillFilipovic

text: Ha that is very precise of you! I always just make a "next time..." mental note, and have a few staples I make a few times a month. (I also suspect this would be very different if I had kids and less time).

text: Totally makes sense.
author: JillFilipovic

text: (That said, if you are one of those people for whom food = fuel and not much else, this is a great way to save money and energy, but I will always be glad I am more of an indulgent hedonist).
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is my nightmare. Weekday breakfast, ok, I will allow it. Leftovers for lunch, fine. But the same dinner every night? When food can be a source of pleasure, let it. (Those of us who love to cook also find food can be a place for creative expression, and that's delightful).
author: JillFilipovic

text: An absolute must-read piece from @Rewire_News: In the US, where abortion is ostensibly legal, public hospitals refuse to perform life-saving procedures on women until they are on the brink of death. How #prolife of them.

text: So are you demanding that of Martha McSally before you will believe or support her? (I believe her).
author: JillFilipovic

text: So yes, Martha McSally and every other woman who speaks out about sexual violence is brave. We owe them more than our Twitter accolades. Maybe take a break from calling me vile garbage scum to ask, "what are the people I vote for doing to decrease sexual violence?"
author: JillFilipovic

text: If you think politics don't matter when it comes to violence against women, you are part of the problem. "Politics" determine funding for domestic violence shelters, research on violence against women, services for survivors, and military policies for assaults in their ranks.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This does not mean conservatives have a monopoly on violence; far from it. But if your "gotcha" is WHY DON'T YOU TALK ABOUT LIBERAL MEN WHO ASSAULT WOMEN?!?!?! you should google first. I write about those men all the time. Here's a recent example:
author: JillFilipovic

text: We know, for example, that when women are refused safe and affordable abortion services, and have babies they are not ready for, they are less likely to leave their abusers and are forced to stay in violent relationships longer.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It is necessary to talk about this, because violence against women does not happen in a vacuum. It is enabled by cultural norms. We know, for example, that men who closely adhere to gender stereotypes are men who are more likely to harm women. The GOP pushes those stereotypes.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And predictably, the right-wing Online Outrage Machine is in full effect. I will reiterate: I think McSally is incredibly brave for speaking out. I also believe the American right has done significant harm to rape survivors and other women who have experienced violence.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Pretty clear on that, thanks for your concern. https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/12/opinions/justin-fairfax-must-resign-democrats-republicans-filipovic/index.html …
author: JillFilipovic

text: If you read my whole thread, I said that she was brave and that this is an important moment. Unfortunately, you are repeatedly, systematically, and disappointingly dishonest.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It would be better, of course, if those experiences led to more humane policy positions (and a tougher look at men in power who stand accused of sexual assault, like Kavanaugh, whose confirmation McSally supported). But things don't change overnight. This is a sign of progress.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think sometimes we don't pause to recognize how far we've come, and how partisan feminist issues of the past are now mainstream & widely accepted. If we can add sexual violence to that list, all the better. Right-wing women speaking out about their experiences is a good thing.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is complicated by the fact that McSally is a member of the exact movement that is hostile to sincere and holistic efforts to combat violence against women, and that folds misogyny into much of its politics. But feminists do want all women to benefit from our gains.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is brave. It's also important. The conservative movement in the US has been staunchly anti-feminist, deriding many women who talk about sexual violence as having a "victim mentality." As a result, there can be a cost to prominent conservative women who speak out.
author: JillFilipovic

text: These asks -- "ay union-level construction wages, donate to affordable housing funds or end its partnership with federal immigration authorities" -- are not huge. What a shame that Amazon won't even do these basics.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is just one part of what needs to be a much larger plan to help American families, but it could pull some 4 million children out of poverty. How sad that it's surely going to be a partisan issue.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And importantly, we can support the choice to end a pregnancy and the choice to pursue one (both of which are legally constrained in some places). We can recognize that life is complicated and messy and few of us get exactly what we want exactly when we want it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Neither childbearing nor empathy are zero-sum games. We can feel for women who struggle to get pregnant and feel for women who are pregnant when they don't want to be. We can recognize that one woman having an abortion has no impact on whether a different woman gets pregnant.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Hello Robert and Ina Caro.
author: JillFilipovic

text: "Different communities hear words differently and we all need to listen, engage and communicate with one another to understand why... sometimes it isn’t our criticism, but how we criticize, that’s problematic." This is such an important read. Thank you @rabiasquared @WajahatAli
author: JillFilipovic

text: Maybe I'm misunderstanding, but as far as I can tell, you asked if it's ok to put women and men in separate roles and still consider them equal - would that be ok? I am saying no. Prescribed separate roles by definition means inequality.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I'm not sure that's true. You can walk away and make clear that you are walking away because of a discriminatory policy, and that you would like to come back should that policy end. If there's no threat of emptying the pews or pulling money, why would the church change?
author: JillFilipovic

text: I don't believe that "separate but equal" is ever equal.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Totally. I'm hearing "it was diverse" from a lot of people. But what does that mean? If we are used to seeing mostly white faces, a rally that's even one-third people of color feels "diverse." But in the context of Flatbush, that's pretty skewed white.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This same thing happens with gender: When women make up 20% or so of a group, we see that group as "equal." When women talk 20% of the time, we perceive their participation as equal. When women are actually 50%, they are perceived to dominate. Perception is not objective.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Also worth recognizing that "diversity" is relative to place and hinges on our perception. For a lot of white people used to mostly-white spaces, a place feels "diverse" if it's 20% people of color. But in a neighborhood that is minority white, that isn't representative.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And by that I don't mean a simple numbers game. I mean thinking about who you believe should support you because your policies and positions are in line with their needs and priorities, and then asking if that support comes through. If not, why not?
author: JillFilipovic

text: This, btw, is something every politician should be doing: Looking at who is showing up to their events, who is supporting them online and off,, and asking who they aren't reaching and how they can cast a wider net.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Some reporting on the lack of diversity at #BernieInBrooklyn (which doesn't mean NO diversity - it means the event was whiter, younger and more male than the community it was held in). Instead of responding with defensiveness, maybe a good chance to ask, "how can this improve?"
author: JillFilipovic

text: Wait. @YousefMunayyer is being called a "terror supporter" now? How disgustingly dishonest, manipulative, and dangerous.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I don't think so either, not any more than you get to women's equality in society through equality in law alone. But that doesn't mean stamping out formal discrimination doesn't matter.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Totally. But the Church has shown no signs it IS changing on the gender front. My own family largely left the church because of its treatment of women. There frankly are not a ton of Catholics loudly arguing for female priests and emptying the pews if discrimination continues.

text: This is very good. Thanks @paulwaldman1
author: JillFilipovic

text: Yep. Gender discrimination, misogyny and the consolidation of male power is wrong no matter what religion, individual or institution justifies it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: When your institution bars women from leadership roles, or separates women and men into different rooms for worship, or has as its very model and ideal of male leaders and female helpmeets, that institution is rotten with misogyny. It is discriminatory. Will you participate?
author: JillFilipovic

text: Until 1978, the Mormon Church banned African Americans from the priesthood and from temples (and of course significant racism remains). That was disgusting, and you can bet I judge every single person who remained a member of the Mormon Church during that time. Do you?
author: JillFilipovic

text: This doesn't just apply to Catholicism, obviously. Lots of religious organizations & institutions formally discriminate on the basis of gender. It's just jarring to see self-identified "progressives" justify that because faith is different (and gender discrimination is different)
author: JillFilipovic

text: This Lent, it's worth considering the institutions we support, and what is worth sacrificing. Do you believe that it's acceptable for women to be systematically barred from positions of authority? Would you join a social club or political party that only allowed men as leaders?
author: JillFilipovic

text: Even his fans know he’s a criminal. They just don’t care because he does what they like. Amazing hypocrisy from the same people who say they want a Great America where people who work hard and play by the rules will succeed.

text: We absolutely should not trade liberty for a false sense of security- for example, TSA security theater. But in important circumstances we should trade it for real security- for example, vaccines, which mean children & the vulnerable don't die in scores from preventable diseases.

text: This story is nuts, and also an example of pretty bad reporting on abortion. For example, they refer to Ryan Magers as a father by virtue of the fact that his girlfriend got pregnant and ended her pregnancy. Hello journalists, words mean things and they matter.

text: I understand (and endorse) criticizing anything that looks like a US plan to use military force for regime change in Venezuela (ditto efforts to manipulate humanitarian aid). I do not understand this move on part of the American left to deny there is a humanitarian crisis at all.
author: JillFilipovic

text: There are many women in Saudi Arabia fighting this system. The government throws them in jail. And the shameless misogynists in power continue to enjoy support from the United States, and a reaction from the rest of the world that ranges from endorsement to indifference.
author: JillFilipovic

text: The problem isn't her choices. The problem is Saudi Arabia's systematic treatment of women as sub-human and wholly dependent on men. Too often, we accept this kind of profoundly destructive gender discrimination as "cultural." It's not: It's political, legally enforced & wrong.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And yes, she willingly married a Saudi man... who presented as kind, progressive, and supportive of her ambitions. She is far from the first person to find her partner becomes someone very different during a marriage, and certainly during a divorce.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Another woman trapped by Saudi Arabia's abusive patriarchy, this one a woman whose husband has been able to render her essentially a non-entity in the country. This is disgusting, and Saudi's treatment of women should make it a pariah state.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Truce!

text: What I see too often is a demand that class supersede race and gender, or a claim that class can be a singular uniting force. I think it's more complicated than that (I also don't think race or gender are singular uniting forces, nor separable).
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think class is an essential part of politics broadly and identity politics specifically. Do I think it's a good thing to unite people based on class interest? Yes. But I think even intra-class interests are complicated by race & gender. They all matter and influence each other.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Every candidate running has some significant weak spot. For Bernie, it's past votes & positions on guns & immigration, plus his general demeanor, which reads as angry, cold and arrogant. Part of picking a fave in the Dem primary will be deciding which weaknesses are dealbreakers.

text: If you think talking about race and gender in addition to class - as things that complicate pure class analysis, and as necessary components of policy discussion - is diluting class analysis, you are the problem, not the “identity politics” you so deride.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course not. I am saying that derisively labeling gender and race consciousness as “identity politics” obscures the fact that identity animates ALL of our politics, and politicians leverage various group identities in all directions.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And so I find it strange that by pointing out all politics that try to shore up support based on group identity are “identity politics,” the result is people claiming I am trying to undermine class politics. Am I trying to undermine gender politics with feminism?
author: JillFilipovic

text: To be clear, I don’t think race, class, gender, & the dumb political identity of “real American” are the same thing - not at all. Nor are race, class and gender identical. But claiming a focus on race and gender is “identity politics” while a focus on class is not it... dishonest
author: JillFilipovic

author: JillFilipovic

text: One big thing I would like to see: some initial concurrent use it or lose it time. Some of the biggest inequalities in a two-parent family begin in those earliest days. One parent (almost always mom) becomes the initial expert, and that just builds on itself.

text: So I’m making these critiques in a spirit of “yes and,” not “this is bad and sexist.” It’s not. I just think a more gender-focused lens would be helpful.

text: And of course that we can’t strip reproductive rights and family planning from policies around the family. These are not two separate things but are profoundly interrelated, and I would like us collectively to be better about recognizing that and talking about the whole package.

text: Even in nations with really generous family policies, women are still having fewer children than they did 50 years ago; women continue to have them later. For many of us, there is no family policy on the planet that would make us have five kids by 30, like my grandma did.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You often see self-described "pro-family" folks say that most Americans have fewer children than they say they want. That's true, but it's more complicated - there is a theoretical number that sounds good, and then there is reality after you have one kid, or simply get older.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It is certainly true that we need the kind of broad benefits outlined here, and that the US is far, far behind other wealthy nations. But giving women the full ability to plan our families involves these benefits AND a full range of reproductive rights and options.
author: JillFilipovic

text: There's a particular strain of softly anti-choice left-wing thought that still sees women primarily as mothers and carers, and assumes that if we simply had more generous family benefits, we would have more babies and have them younger. I'm not sure that's true.
author: JillFilipovic

text: 6. Finally, it's crucial to talk about family planning in any proposal around families, and that is conspicuously absent here. A whole lot of people remain unable to plan the families that they want, which contributes to broader instability and thwarts a lot of potential.

text: Agreed (my family is Catholic, but many left the church when it turned its back on my grandmother for leaving her abusive husband). In any case, I hear you that many individual Catholics of course oppose racism or sexism. But I do think we need to be honest about the institution.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I don't deny that there are a great many Catholic individuals who hold progressive views and abhor misogyny & racism. But at the end of the day, the institution is one that systematically excludes women from positions of power. Misogyny isn't an unfortunate outcome; it's baked in
author: JillFilipovic

text: I just wonder at what point the institution is so flawed from top to bottom that holding it accountable has to mean not supporting it. These are not random people weaponizing Catholicism in support of misogyny. It's the entire power structure and leadership.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sure. But the institution itself makes choices & it has figureheads who have significant power -- the Pope, the Bishops. Their choices guide how these issues are taught & understood. The Pope choice to canonize Serra & stigmatize abortion. The US Bishops enable clinic harassment.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Absolutely. And Catholics have abortions at the same rates as other American women. My point is that misogyny & racism (and erasing the Church's long history of misogyny & racism) are upheld and perpetrated by the institution. That contributes to dehumanizing acts like this one.
author: JillFilipovic

text: For example, here is the US Conference of Catholic Bishops in an amicus brief to the Supreme Court, asking them to invalidate a law creating a buffer zone around a Boston abortion clinic to protect women from harassment. This is an institutional problem. http://www.usccb.org/about/general-counsel/amicus-briefs/upload/cls-amicus-brief-filed.pdf …

text: (Which doesn't mean scrutiny is bad! Scrutiny is good. But context is also good and necessary -- including a hard look at how we systematically exclude women and people of color from powerful positions by holding them to high and conflicting expectations).
author: JillFilipovic

text: You may still decide that Harris's choices as a prosecutor are disqualifying. She certainly should be asked about them. But I would frankly love to see the records of white male faves get anywhere close to this much scrutiny on issues of criminal justice, guns, women's rights etc
author: JillFilipovic

text: Btw these are two responses to this thread posted nearly back to back, just while we're talking about the impossible expectations women face.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Absolutely.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And just yelling "Kamala Harris is a cop!" or "Kamala Harris was the most progressive prosecutor of all time" is very far from the whole story.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Which doesn't mean we shouldn't change bad systems or that we shouldn't press Harris on her record. We should! But context also matters. Gender and race matter. How we treat white male candidates matters. This is all imperfect and complicated but it's necessary to flesh out.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Now, the rules have shifted (and I don't think it's a coincidence that they shifted right as more women began succeeding within the system). And not just that, but women and people of color face much harsher scrutiny than white men when they run for office.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Understand too that the path for women to power has radically shifted in the past few years. For so long women were required to be non-threatening but tough on crime & foreign policy, and told that raising money was one of the biggest barriers to female electoral success.
author: JillFilipovic

text: But know that the second she apologizes for her decisions as a prosecutor so that the left will support her (and many never will), that will be used against her in a general election to suggest she is a soft on crime Antifa Black Lives Matter radical. White men do not face that.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Women have to prove that they are "tough." Black women have to prove that they are fair and rational. Again, that doesn't excuse some of Harris's choices when she was a prosecutor, and I hope she is asked about them and has good answers (including a mea culpa).
author: JillFilipovic

text: White men don't live with these expectations and they are under much less scrutiny (even when they run for president), which perversely gives them a lot more space to take risks. That's part of why I personally judge them a bit more harshly when they refuse to take those risks.
author: JillFilipovic

text: They also shoulder additional burdens. Some expected Harris to have been more progressive because she's a black woman & should therefore be accountable to her community; others were on high alert for her being TOO progressive & allegedly putting "identity politics" before her job
author: JillFilipovic

text: People who stand out because they occupy roles that have not traditionally been occupied by people like them fall under much more intense scrutiny. That's true of Harris as a prosecutor, and it's now true of Harris as a presidential contender.
author: JillFilipovic

text: The second is that identity does matter here, and Harris was undoubtedly under enormous pressure to prove herself to be "tough" -- especially as a woman, ESPECIALLY as a black woman. That doesn't excuse the worst excesses, but it does contextualize the many demands on her.
author: JillFilipovic

text: The first is that, as Bazelon writes, Harris did do a lot of good during her time as a prosecutor, pushing more progressive policies. But she was indeed also a prosecutor, and did what prosecutors do, which is not very progressive (she also went beyond that on several occasions).
author: JillFilipovic

text: A good piece by @larabazelon on what may be Kamala Harris's achilles heel with progressives: Her time as a prosecutor. But there are a few important things to add before you go all "Kamala is a cop":

text: I'm actually not aware of any Kenyan laws on news outlets publishing images of dead bodies - if they exist I would love to see them. (I've seen a media guide, but that's not a law).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Which is part of the reason why these ideals and norms really, really matter: Because while foreign correspondents take great risks, it's usually not the NYT correspondent who pays with her life or freedom when journalism is deemed inconvenient or a threat to national security.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It's also worth noting here that Kenya has no shortage of brave and talented journalists. The reality is that foreign correspondents get to leave if shit gets bad, and are MUCH less likely to be killed or jailed by a hostile government. Domestic journalists take those risks.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I am heartened to see the degree to which Twitter has democratized conversations, and allowed people who are being reported on the space to criticize that reporting. The conversation about these photos is crucial. But that can happen without subverting the ideal of a free press.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So yes, I am disturbed to see demands to deport a reporter from a country that just experienced another terrorist attack, especially knowing what happened after the Westgate attacks (which was: No full accounting; abuses of Somali men; extrajudicial killings, etc).
author: JillFilipovic

text: (We've seen left-wing authoritarians do this too. This isn't really about right / left, but more about authoritarianism and how national security is often (always?) a pretext for making sure no independent observers or reporters have their eyes on wrongdoing.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We've seen too many journalists silenced in China, in Hungary, in Myanmar, in Turkey, in Egypt, in Nigeria, in Burundi... and we've seen autocratic leaders in the US and elsewhere use this playbook. We've seen "national security" used as the excuse every time.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We see autocrats claiming that "the people" don't trust the press, that only the autocrat's version of events is true, that reporters are liars, that they deserve to be kicked out of press rooms or entire countries. This is the pretext to silence dissent and prevent investigation
author: JillFilipovic

text: So why bring this up now and focus on demands to deport the reporter instead the photo itself? Here is why: Because there is a rise in right-wing authoritarianism around the world, and terrorism / threats of terrorism are systematically used to squelch a free press.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think that’s totally fair, and should be a part of the conversation. My issue is solely with the demands to kick a reporter out of the country because of her newspaper photo desk’s policy (and how that policy was implemented here).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sure. I don’t dispute that there are valid criticisms. My point is that demands for deportation are explicit attacks on a free press and have a chilling effect on the press.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think it’s important to have a conversation about whether it was appropriate or not to publish the photo. But even if we agree it was inappropriate, that doesn’t justify deporting a reporter. That’s what I have an issue with.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That kind of transparent accounting would go a long way to improving how major outlets report and image violence. I do think showing death and destruction is sometimes appropriate. But it shouldn’t depend on place or race - even if that’s unintentional.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And not just what was published, but what wasn’t. Look at the universe of what was filed to get a sense of how publication choices were made. Were there situations where photo editors declined to publish images like the one from Nairobi? Where did that happen and why?
author: JillFilipovic

text: I will say I think there is an opportunity here for the Times to rebuild some trust by taking a thorough look at its terrorism coverage over the past decade or so. Actually study how victims are portrayed in photos, including bodies and blood etc, and publish the results.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I have spent much more time writing about Trump voters than just about any other single topic in the past two years. I also write about attacks on press freedom because they are disturbing and wrong.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That’s fine that you think that, and is why you have your own twitter account.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Because that’s not the point...? Plenty of people are engaged in the debate about whether the photo should have been published. I can see both sides. I do not think “deport a journalist” is a valid and fair place to take the discussion.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think there’s valid a debate about whether it should have been published. You really don’t see how demands to report a journalist,l (who is not the photo editor) because you think her newspaper shouldn’t have published a photo isn’t an attack on the free press?
author: JillFilipovic

text: Because I have no issue with people critiquing the photo and I don’t usually tweet about things that I think are fine and have no problem with.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And I’m a journalist who stands against attacks on the free press, wherever and whenever they happen.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not telling them what they can or can’t do. They can do whatever they want! I have no power there. But this is Twitter so we can also talk about it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So you think it’s fair to deport a reporter over this?
author: JillFilipovic

text: You don’t have to condone it. But demanding reporters are deported because you (fairly!) disagree with her newspaper’s photo policy - which is very standard across media outlets, although I agree unequally implemented - is an unjust and unwarranted attack on the free press.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I also don’t take issue with anyone’s tone. I take issue with demands to deport a journalist because people (fairly!) disagree with her newspaper’s photo policy.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If you want context for the deportation comments you are welcome to click the link in my first tweet, or search #deportkimiko on twitter. It’s not rare.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Well then perhaps there is a comprehension issue. I never say that critiquing the photo is an attack on the free press. In fact i say the opposite approximately 16 times: that it’s a conversation that should be had.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Again, I think a lot of the critiques are totally valid and it’s an important conversation. But “deport this journalist” is not a critique. It is an attack on a free and open press. That’s what I’m taking issue with.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You should read the thread and respond to what I actually said. I’m not saying it’s an attack to critique the photos. I’m saying it’s an attack to demand a journalist be deported because you disagree with the Times’s photo policy.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Again, I think the critiques are fair and important. I think it crosses a line to demand a reporter (who didn’t even choose the photos) be deported. That is the issue I’m criticizing. Not conversation and even anger over the photo itself.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Those women are Trumpian and awful and I’ve written about them many, many times. I’ve also written about attacks on the free press in a wide variety of contexts.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I think there are valid critiques of the photos and a fair argument for not publishing them. I do not think that justifies demanding the deportation of a reporter.
author: JillFilipovic

text: She’s not the one who chose the photo and I’ll bet had no idea what any of the photos published with her story would be. And while I think critiques of the photo are valid, there is nothing about it that violates standard journalistic ethics.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Wowowowow
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway I think there are many legitimate critiques of how American media covers violence in Africa. Those should be made. But I’m disturbed by demands to (a) deport a reporter, and (b) to not cover anything other than heroics.
author: JillFilipovic

text: A Burst of Gunfire, a Pause, Then Carnage in Las Vegas That Would Not Stop
author: JillFilipovic

text: There is a photo of dead bodies in the article I linked.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Totally fair - I don’t necessary agree, but I think it’s an entirely fair point. As I said many times, the discussion is important. This thread, though, is about the antidemocratic and authoritarian attacks on a free press demonstrates by those calls to deport journalists.
author: JillFilipovic

text: A lot of the photos do indeed show heroics. But the job of a journalist is not propaganda. It’s truth-telling. And part of the truth of terrorist attacks is that they kill and injure people.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You don’t need to take my word for it. It’s discussed in the piece I initially linked, and very easy to spot if you search the word “Nairobi” or #DeportKimiko on twitter.
author: JillFilipovic

text: (And if I’m being honest I wish there was as much outrage at the Kenyan government for still not issuing a full accounting of what happened at Westgate as there is at the Times for a photo).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Again, I think it’s fair to debate those things. I do not think it’s fair to demand that the journalist be deported or refused a visa.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And that’s a totally fair critique and a fine one to debate, as I said. But it crossed a big line when the critique turns into “deport the reporter.”
author: JillFilipovic

text: Their policy is to not publish images of identifiable dead bodies. As I linked, they absolutely publish photos of unidentifiable American bodies.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not sure that’s a fair take. The Times published its policy on photos of the dead, which this photo clearly fell within. Lots of folks disagree with the policy, but that the Times didn’t do what people asked them to is... often how journalism works.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I know a lot of people are hurting from yesterday’s #RiversidedriveAttack in Nairobi, and a photo of dead people touched a particular point of pain at a particularly raw moment. Anger is human. But retreating from a dedication to openness and a free press is the wrong response.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And those critiques should be made. It’s good to have a dialogue and even heated debate about this. But that debate has to be grounded in both truth and a dedication to a free press. Too much of what I’m seeing reflects neither, and that’s really disapppinting and disturbing.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s also not true that American newspapers never publish photos of dead bodies of Americans. Here’s the Times’s coverage of the Las Vegas attack:  https://nyti.ms/2fJwpwV?smid=nytcore-ios-share … That said, I think there are fair critiques that American publications are more careful with white bodies.
author: JillFilipovic

text: For example, the calls to deport the Times correspondent. The the response to a newspaper publishing a photo you think was insensitive and wrong to publish cannot be to kick the reporter (who doesn’t make photo decisions - that’s the photo desk) out of the country.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s so frustrating to see this. Not the critiques of the photo - I take issue with many of those, but conversations around what images of death and terror newspapers publish is an important one - but the profoundly antidemocratic and positively Trumpian attacks on the free press
author: JillFilipovic

text: I suppose the point is: there are people who do shockingly evil things. And there are so many more people who do extraordinary good in the most awful of circumstances. Shocking evil was on display today at 14 Riverside, but photos show there was so much more extraordinary good.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Whoops sorry here’s Tristan’s piece:
author: JillFilipovic

text: Yes of course. Sorry if that wasn’t clear.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Say goodbye to functional plumbing and hello to a massive plumber bill next (or fish that thing out by hand, either way, I am sure Gillette misses your business).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Thank you! It’s nice to get some positive feedback. I appreciate you taking the time.
author: JillFilipovic

text: (I suspect they may be private citizens who sped to the attack to see if they could rescue people because that’s what many brave folks did in the Westgate attacks, an incredible detail in this @t_mcconnell reconstruction).
author: JillFilipovic

text: There’s a Mr. Rogers quote that always gets passed around after mass tragedies: look for the helpers. Lots of helpers in these photos, including journos going above & beyond. Also noticing S. Asian men with handguns and suspect they may be private citizens who showed up to help.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I mean this is just a hunch but maybe you would be better off personally, professionally and romantically if you found a hobby more productive than flying into a semi-literate rage because an ad exec was like, “here’s an idea, maybe men are capable of being good and kind humans”
author: JillFilipovic

text: This piece has been up for 10 minutes and I’ve gotten more hysterical tweets about it than anything else I’ve written in recent memory. You Tough Guys are extremely sensitive and also seem to spend a LOT of time trawling twitter for the word “Gillette.”
author: JillFilipovic

text: Lol this is in response to a piece that was written for a section called “CNN Opinion,” and also no one is making you read it, respond to it or even think about it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And that’s 100% an important conversation to have. But I’m really uncomfortable with twitter censoring legitimate news sources and having such outsized control over journalism. Debating the value of certain images is important. So is a free press.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not sure it’s true that the media doesn’t show injured / unidentifiable dead white people (Boston marathon bombing, the Las Vegas shootings, American soldiers dragged through the streets of Mogadishu, etc). That said I agree many news orgs are more careful w/ domestic photos.
author: JillFilipovic

text: In other words, you can believe two things at once: that publishing a photo with dead people in it was the wrong call, and also that twitter content monitors are perhaps the wrong people to be deciding what credible media outlets publish in a fast-moving breaking news moment.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Which doesn’t mean I think the criticisms of the Times are wrong or unwarranted, although I do think it’s more complicated than how some frame it. But suspending the account of one the best & most important newspapers in the world in the midst of a terror attack is a bad call.
author: JillFilipovic

text: There are not easy answers to the questions of which images of death & injury should be published; this is also complicated by race and place. Those conversations must continue (here’s a good primer: https://niemanreports.org/articles/how-newsrooms-handle-graphic-images-of-violence/ …). But I’m disturbed that @twitter suspended @nytphoto.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I am pondering how wonderful this is.

text: And "policy" matters in very broad terms. Most voters have no idea what each candidate's actual record is - what matters more are narratives around who is "moderate" or "liberal" or whatever, and those often don't square with reality. Most voters are tribal, not detail-focused.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course policy matters to a lot of voters. But politicians too often assume that voters' views are set, and their job is to chase those votes. Instead, views on policy can shift and change rapidly depending on narrative and framing. THAT is a politician's job: Sell good policy.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Narratives absolutely matter. But the narratives around policy can shift voters' policy positions. Too many politicians see it the other way around, assuming voters' views are set and their job is to adhere to those views.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So yes, it's a good thing that lefty Dems push the rest of the party left. It's also a smart thing to consider whoever excites and inspires you. That combination - exciting/inspiring AND good on policy - is a very doable thing in this election.
author: JillFilipovic

text: "Should Democrats run a moderate or a lefty?" misses the fact that the overwhelming majority of voters don't actually vote on policy at all, and the theory that racing to the middle will secure more votes is wrong.

text: If you want to make a list of easy, affordable and accessible places within the US, definitely do that - that is a great list! But if you're making a global list, it should be global instead of weighted toward America.

text: Luckily I didn’t argue that it’s “just” a right-wing spin machine. And I say that there are a lot of criticisms coming from within feminist communities. But just because you haven’t seen the years-long attacks from the right doesn’t mean they haven’t been significant.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sometimes that means leaders step down. It doesn’t mean drumming them out of progressive activism, but it does mean there is a point where we can (and must) say anti-Semitism (and support of anti-Semitism or any other bigoted ideology) disqualifies you as a paid feminist leader.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If we don’t believe people can and should change, what are we doing in progressive politics? At the same time, we can also say that our leaders deserve the same space to grow, but as leaders there’s a higher base line they should be starting from - and higher expectations.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And understanding this context is crucial to figuring out how we build sustainable progressive movements led by mere humans, all of whom have blind spots and bigotries, some much more pronounced than others. Where do we draw hard lines? How do we allow for grace and evolution?
author: JillFilipovic

text: In my opinion, even within that fuller context, the kind of anti-Semitism we’ve seen from at least one WM leader is disqualifying for leadership in this particular movement. But recognizing that context is crucial to understanding the inter-feminist debates happening now.
author: JillFilipovic

text: To be clear, the New York Times piece is not part of a right-wing spin machine or a smear campaign. It’s a good piece of reporting. But there has been a year of right-wing smears, many outright lies or racist exaggerations. People are operating from within that fuller context.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not saying that confronting Tamika about her actual words was a racist smear campaign. There is much more context and much longer history than this one NYT article.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I hope that they can take a step back and work to separate out attacks from right-wing hate-mongers from the critiques of many feminist women who were rooting for their success but who are now feeling (rightly) betrayed, angry and abandoned by their own community.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I don’t have a personal relationship with any of the leaders of the women’s march, and I have different feelings about each of them. It’s worth recognizing that they have felt under attack all year, and are reacting from that place - which is human, if not the most productive.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Not wanting to push out women of color or join what has been all mixed up with a racist smear campaign, and also wanting genuine accountability (and even resignation) from leaders who espouse anti-Semitism. While also wanting to model the best of progressive politics.
author: JillFilipovic

text: What I see and hear off of Twitter is that many feminists are genuinely torn - appalled by anti-Semitism from women we admired, also appalled by how the right-wing spin machine has helped to turn a grain of truth into a much larger and uglier and less-honest narrative...
author: JillFilipovic

text: Many other women see the anti-Semitism (or apology for anti-Semitism) in some of the women’s march leaders’ words and actions and are horrified and appalled and are wondering why their progressive community doesn’t stand for them, too. This is also true.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Many women rightly see a leadership of women of color coming under predictable attack - as always, as soon as women of color have some power, there’s a huge backlash, a series of smear campaigns, and attempts to take them down. This is true.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I have a hard time thinking anyone who is a dedicated feminist can hear what Farrakhan says about women and stay in the room and clap. But then, it’s become basically impossible to discuss the women’s march within feminist communities at this point.
author: JillFilipovic

text: But what I also see are leaders who feel pulled by the demands of various constituencies and at least some of whom don’t have a whole lot of history in feminist organizing. Not that they aren’t great organizers for other causes, but feminism seems to be somewhat new.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And that’s very frustrating. There also does seem to be, to put it generously, a huge blind spot when it comes to Jewish people - and yes, some obvious anti-Semitism. Must we give people the grace and the ability to grow and learn? Absolutely. I do see the march leaders trying.
author: JillFilipovic

text: What I would like to see is genuine accountability. I will say I’ve seen Linda in particular make sincere efforts there. But overall we’ve heard mealy-mouthed claims that March leaders don’t reject individuals (like Farrakhan), but they do disagree with (some of) his ideas.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is a good thread with a different perspective. I do think it’s valuable that progressive movements don’t focus on “taking down” those who are perceived to be imperfect. There’s far too much of that. But also, we cannot abide bigotry in the name of unity.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Yes. And as far as I can tell, the critiques all around are not coordinated attacks or “clearing the field.” Some people really like their candidate and are going to dislike perceived challengers. (It also wasn’t “clearing the field” in 2016 when this dynamic happened w/ Clinton)

text: In this particular political universe, with a president who consistently lies and a staff who gets behind those lies and is willing to repeat them, the administration is playing by different rules. It doesn’t seem like newsrooms have figured out how to adjust.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s easy to criticize from the sidelines and in hindsight. If I were an editor I would have assigned stories on the caravan too. But between this and the Clinton email coverage, which has never really been addressed, there is obviously an issue of good journalists getting played
author: JillFilipovic

text: Plus there’s an impulse to truth-tell and clear up the lies and misperceptions. I think that’s what happened here. But it resulted in several front-page stories feeding a president’s propaganda machine. That’s very obvious now. Is there an internal reckoning?
author: JillFilipovic

text: I say that without rudeness or sarcasm. Making these calls is not easy, especially when you have a president saying this is an emergency, you have right-wing media covering it breathlessly, and there’s the perpetual claim that truth-telling and proportionality = “liberal.”
author: JillFilipovic

text: Hopefully there are some discussions happening in the newsrooms of our country’s biggest papers and TV networks about how not to get duped again into giving front-page treatment to marginal stories designed to rally a racist political movement.

text: Hate speech is not criminalized - it is protected speech (direct threats etc are not, but "hate speech," as a broad category, won't get you arrested). Lakoff seems to be saying that we should put hate speech in a similar category as physical violence (not protected by 1st Am).
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is where I often find myself in conflict with other progressive people I admire and respect. I (obviously) do not like hate speech. I think it is harmful. I think we should counter it. But I also think it pretty clearly falls under American First Amendment protections.
author: JillFilipovic

text: These issues interlock. This was an act of anti-Semitic violence, but it was also motivated by hatred of immigrants and non-whites. This is not new. The “globalist” is a Jew, and the sin of the “globalist” is always this - bringing in unfamiliar, dangerous outsiders.

text: Do you stand against those who use bigotry to rile up their base? Do you stand against those who rely on anti-Semitic dogwhistles (“globalists” and George Soros) to point angry followers toward an enemy?

text: Yes. These rallies are not newsworthy. They are an authoritarian leader’s vanity project, giving him a free platform to promote extremism and anti-democratic values. A free press should not aid and abet him.

text: Right-wing media stoking fears about an “immigrant caravan” descending on the nation is part of this story. And I realize mainstream outlets feel an obligation to cover it as a public truth-telling service, but is it really front-page news that there are migrants 1200 miles away?
author: JillFilipovic

text: These are the perfect conditions for violence to thrive. These aren’t lone wackos. They are part of a system that encourages predictable behavior. We can obsess over each individual, or we can commit to changing the landscape that feeds them. I think, sadly, we know what we’ll do
author: JillFilipovic

text: I would bet that some folks who have committed acts of right-wing violence, and some who will in the future, will be anti-Trump because he didn’t do enough to protect white America. Trump defenders will see this as exculpatory. It’s not - it’s part of the system he helped to grow
author: JillFilipovic

text: They see that the president thinks violence against his opponents is funny. They see that mainstream GOP groups accept violent fascist self-styled militias like the Proud Boys. They hear the president say he’s unable to implement his agenda because of bad people who challenge him
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course there are going to be unhinged individuals in your movement. What they’ve heard is that their worst impulses weren’t wrong at all - that was all PC liberal lies - and that they are under threat.
author: JillFilipovic

text: When you tell people that a very unfair thing is happening, and that they are victimized by a powerful, shady group - CNN, Democratic politicians, Jewish globalists like George Soros, liberals who threaten their first and second amendment rights - you instill fear and mistrust.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Trump encouraged them to breathe & grow. People who may have been predisposed to hate and bigotry but would have been socially nudged in a different direction are now swimming in very different social tides. As you welcome in what was once extreme, the most extreme are emboldened
author: JillFilipovic

text: It’s not that these ideas are new or that they had been nearly done away with. But there were efforts from many of our social gatekeepers - some elected officials, some of the mainstream media - to starve them of oxygen.
author: JillFilipovic

text: For so many people, the external noise around them - from their TV, from their political leaders, from their religious leaders, from their friends and colleagues - has broadened to include ideas that were previously considered out of bounds for being bigoted & factually incorrect
author: JillFilipovic

text: Many (most?) people have had hateful thoughts. Whether you feel ashamed or proud of that, though, is social. Whether your internal narrative interrogates where that thought is coming from or whether it hears that thought as reflecting the truth depends on external narratives.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Human beings are social animals. We take our cues from those around us. We respond to hierarchy and organization. We know that conservative / traditional values also emphasize deference to authority. Normalizing bigotry in a population is part of how hate explodes into violence.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It turns out that a white identity politic that casts everyone else as bad, dishonest and potentially dangerous is very good for Republicans at the ballot box. This has been true since the southern strategy, but Trump ramped it up, and the party has kept the momentum going.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Racism, misogyny, anti-Semitism, xenophobia, all of these things have always existed in America. But they aren’t static; it’s not that people are either racist or not and the question is whether they say it out loud. You can absolutely fuel more racism, or you can temper it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Trump latched onto this and ran with it, but the population was primed for a leader like him. He welcomed in the fringe. As he was made more normal and acceptable, and as his followers grew bolder and louder, the boundary of what was considered “too far” grew wider and wider.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This propaganda apparatus has helped to convince millions of people that they are the victims of an unholy alliance of liberals, globalists, and dangerous foreigners. It has convinced an astounding number of people that everyone lies to them, except, conveniently, them.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Right-wing media has successfully fed into this narrative of white grievance. Even now, they insist that Clinton saying you can’t be civil with people who want to destroy you is evidence of left-wing incivility. Shooting up a synagogue isn’t uncivil. It’s hate-fueled violence.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That’s the top, but again, it’s not a straight line. We also have a Republican Party that goes along with him, aiding in normalizing ideas that have always animated the right, but that were at least hidden away by more respectable Republicans. We have a right-wing propaganda arm.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We have a president who suggests that there is a vast conspiracy to harm good Americans - by which he means white Americans - made up of Democrats who want to aid the undeserving, a news media that lies and cannot be trusted, & a cabal of wealthy “globalists” who are all Jewish.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We have a president who endorses this view. Does he say “mail bombs to prominent politicians and CNN”? No. But he does say that some of those same politicians should be in jail, and suggests that they’re not only because of a great injustice (and political conspiracy).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Whether they feel empowered, emboldened, or inflamed to act out isn’t a pre-set inevitability. Yes, sometimes you get a single unstable person who acts. But what we’re seeing now are a bunch of people all acting out of the same general worldview - right-wing white nationalism.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That is, it’s not a simple A to B of “someone powerful says something hateful and then his followers pick up guns.” Rather, it’s a more complex interconnected system. There are people who are prone to violence, and their views span many political ideologies.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We’re going to spend the next weeks debating whether inflammatory rhetoric causes violence, what counts as inflammatory, whether political ideologies premised on white male grievances and resentment of minoirites beget violence. It’s worth remembering that hate is an ecosystem.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Did I say anything partisan? I criticized anti-Semitic dog whistles from any political leader.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Antisemitism is deadly. And when our leaders spread anti-Semitic conspiracy theories - like claiming George Soros funds fake protesters and is determined to undermine America - it feeds and encourages dangerous people.
