text: Anyway, I could go on about this forever (and I have!) but suffice it to say, don’t trust a narrative that paints an entire continent of women as monolithic, assumes feminism is a western import, or suggests that “have babies / don’t have babies” is the heart of any debate.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And who doesn’t seem to grasp that “African women,” like, say, “European women” may have a lot of different perspectives, opinions and experiences - including many who want more expansive opportunities, and many who think tradition is great. Welcome to every society ever.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway, there is a lot to be said about the toxicity of the entire concept of “population control” and how racist fear-mongering has indeed fueled bad, misogynist policy. But this is a whole piece about African women from a guy who seems to have never talked to an African woman.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’ve reported on these issues from a dozen-plus countries. The advocates, doctors, nurses, midwives, community health workers and others who provide crucial services and push for women’s rights are not outsiders. Casting women’s rights as a western idea is part of the problem.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Again, in reality, a lot of women (and some men) have long been doing the slow, often thankless work of pursuing gender equality and opening up more opportunities for women in their own communities, cities and countries. It’s frustrating to see that work erased.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Unless of course you are under the impression that white European / American women are the only ones who have historically tried to time their pregnancies or advocated for their own equality and opportunity, which seems to be one assumption in the piece.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Are some European leaders and voters motivated by racism? Uh, yeah - just look at their immigration policies. But that does not in turn make long-standing development efforts, including opportunities for women (which includes reproductive rights) inherently suspect.
author: JillFilipovic

text: In reality, advocates for women recognize that just throwing contraception at women doesn’t do much good if women don’t have a full range of opportunities. Education, work for pay, social and legal equality to men, ability to choose who to marry - all these things tie together.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It is convenient for him, as someone who is generally skeptical of women planning their families and using contraception and abortion to do it, to cast efforts toward broader reproductive rights for all women as racist population control.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Shrugging that off (as Douthat does) is irresponsible. It would also be cruel and wrong-headed to take that info and decide “we must prevent African women from having babies.” Contrary to what Douthat seems to think, that’s not really what’s happening.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Do demographers and researchers look at population trends and make predictions, many of them not very pretty? Yes. For example: population growth fuels climate change, which is in turn already fueling conflict and constraining resources.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Is there certainly an ugly history (and in some places, present) of population control efforts? Yes. We have to be vigilant about that. But when you look at what advocates for women are doing on the ground, contraception is just one part of much broader efforts.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Do researchers and scientists look at birth rates and assess their impact on things like the environment, extremism, poverty, etc? Yes they do! And they should - that is their job. It’s condescending to women to suggest it’s offensive to even discuss family size and reproduction.
author: JillFilipovic

text: None of that is about “have fewer babies.” It’s about giving women options and creating the circumstances in which she can choose how many babies she wants to have. It’s about creating opportunities for women other than hoping one son will maybe be able to provide for the family.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We know that educated women tend to have fewer children and invest more resources in each one. Those children are more likely live into adulthood. They are more likely to be immunized. That woman is less likely to die in childbirth. She’s more likely to educate her daughter.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Having seen organizations like @MarieStopes work on the ground, they aren’t telling women “have fewer babies.” They are saying, “use contraception between pregnancies so you can space them out and not put your life in danger.” This is life-saving care for women and children.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And many of the largest families occur in places where plural marriage is common, men have multiple wives, and men hoard resources and power. More kids means a bigger share of resources / inheritance.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Maybe one child goes on to be a doctor or works in Europe or the US. More kids means more potential. Large families are often also started when mothers are quite young. Babies mean joy, ability to play - something a lot of girls who worked hard & married young never really got.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Having actually talked to women Douthat theorizes about - women who have or want to have large families, living in very poor places - their choices are pretty logical given their circumstances. There aren’t any resources, so each child is another chance at potential prosperity.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You can’t separate out reproductive rights - access to contraception, abortion, and the ability to plan one’s family - from broader development goals. You have to be able to talk about population and its relationship to development and the environment.
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is one of the most disingenuous and least thoughtful articles on Africa and birth rates I’ve ever read. And as someone who reports on these exact issues, I’ve read a lot!
author: JillFilipovic

text: Should health care providers have some leeway in deciding that they don't want to partake in certain procedures? Sure. But the patient should always be able to get the medication or procedure they need with zero delay.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Should medical providers be allowed to discriminate in treatment based on who the patient is? (i.e., a nurse refusing to treat a trans woman because she objected to her "lifestyle," or a religious male doctor refusing to touch female patients?) Absolutely not.

text: What would more balanced conscience laws look like? Medical providers could object to providing medications / particular procedures provided there was a willing provider on the premises and immediately available. That way patients get services without humiliation & delay.

text: Cool. Tell it to CUNY. Also you are really a champion at missing the point here.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sure. But my point is, putting aside the question of whether the term is anti-semiitic or not, should universities allow offensive speech (even if it's not offensive to everyone)? I think yes.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I'm not saying that at all. You're pretty much proving my point here: That we want to quibble about semantics, but that does not help to establish clear rules around speech.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Again, great that that's your opinion. But a lot of folks feel differently, especially given the history of terms like "Zionist propaganda," which have inarguably been used to further anti-Semitism. But in any case, this is my exact point: Debating the content doesn't help.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That's great that you don't think that. But obviously a lot of people do, and see "sick Zionist propaganda" as anti-Semitic. Do we want universities to then be the arbiters of what's acceptable speech and what's up for debate or not?
author: JillFilipovic

text: Totally. I'm not debating whether it's offensive or not. I'm not sure that matters. The question is, is offensive speech acceptable at public universities? Where / when / to what extent?
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course that said, I think many of us would feel differently if he used, say, the n-word or the c-word or another slur. So I don't know! Making hard-and-fast rules about this stuff is very hard and anyone who pretends it's not has not thought much about it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: But it does mean that you don't get called into the dean's office and face down a discrimination case for calling something Zionist propaganda.
author: JillFilipovic

text: That doesn't mean nobody gets to push back. It doesn't mean this guy gets to be immune from accusations of anti-Semitism. It doesn't mean that if a student uses, say, bad unsubstantiated race "science" in a term paper that they won't deservedly fail the class for poor coursework.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I am of the general belief that universities stand for the free exchange of ideas, including offensive ones, or ones that are offensive to some (and I would feel the same way if the issue was a student calling something "sick feminist propaganda").
author: JillFilipovic

text: These are not as easy of questions as we might hope. Some of it depends on the speaker and the context - someone who has power over another and uses language that suggests they will treat that person differently is one case. Someone who makes a comment on a listserve is another.
author: JillFilipovic

text: We can argue over whether the phrase "sick Zionist propaganda" is hateful language (I think it's dumb language and it made me roll my eyes), but that's neither here nor there. Should universities punish discrimination? Yes. Is "triggering speech" discrimination? Is "hate speech"?
author: JillFilipovic

text: An interesting case that exposes some of the tensions between social justice movements that want to (understandably) police hateful language and civil liberties ideals that value free speech as a broad concept (not just a legal one).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Totally. Bu my point is that even if she didn’t intend to kill him when she walked in that house, the norm of cops shooting at anyone who doesn’t adequately obey them is totally insane.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Police should serve (and of course many do), not just act as if they’re all-powerful enforcers who you must please and obey. But we have so internalized this view that cops can shoot to kill at very little provocation. That is just not how protecting and serving should work.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I have no idea what happened in that apartment. But it does certainly seem like cops are not trained to use force as a last resort, and are fed a narrative of embattlement and ultimate authority (the proliferation of military toys to police forces doesn’t help).
author: JillFilipovic

text: If that was the norm, cops would certainly still do terrible things - human beings are human, and we tend to be extra terrible when we have authority. But that baseline would really shift expectations. This cop wouldn’t be able to use the “he didn’t listen” defense.
author: JillFilipovic

text: It means that you don’t shoot someone who holds a knife. It means you don’t shoot someone for failing to follow your commands. It means you only use deadly force if you are at immediate risk of being killed. Your job should be to protect public safety & difuse bad situations.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I am sure this will get me in trouble for reasons I honestly don’t totally understand, but my view is that being a police officer should involve a degree of sacrifice and willingness to put your life on the line. It means there should be a reasonable bar for self-defense.
author: JillFilipovic

text: While it’s easy to poke holes in her obviously invented story, it seems like a fundamental problem is that we’ve largely accepted this insane rule that cops can shoot people who are not a direct and immediate threat to their lives.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I don’t think it’s birtherism - it’s not a conspiracy theory about where she was born! It’s a woman saying she was an immigrant when she was born and raised in Florida. That she traveled back and forth to Colombia has a kid doesn’t make her an immigrant.

text: Well... she claimed that as a Jew she was raised with a particular view of Israel. But she wasn't raised Jewish (that's not in dispute). She has claimed multiple times that she's an immigrant (including on video). She is not. That seems pretty willful, no?

text: So that's odd. Plus she at times claimed to be an immigrant, when she wasn't. I dunno. I really like her politics and I am so glad to see young women running. I think the intense scrutiny on her is because she's a young woman. But still, the lying gives me serious pause.

text: It's not just that some people are drawing lines around Jewishness. It's that Salazar claimed her father was Jewish, and said she "was raised with the delusion that Israel was a safe haven for me, perhaps even the only safe place for Jews." She was raised Christian / agnostic.

text: None of this is to say “yay Ellison!” or defend him; neither is it to say he should definitely go. It is to say that these are tough questions and I don’t know the answers. I obviously think physical abuse is a hard line. I’m torn on accusations of “narcissistic abuse.”

text: I guess the question is, how much should a person’s behavior in their intimate relationships - short of physical violence - be taken into account when assessing whether they should be disqualified from public office or admiration?

text: Monaghan’s chief accusation is of “narcissistic abuse.” I’m not sure where we draw the line. Emotional abuse is a real thing. Men who treat women badly but not violently in the workplace - sexually harassing them, for example - should obviously pay a professional price.

text: I know. I addressed that in the next tweet.

text: As long as a male monopoly power is part of your organization, and especially if deference to authority and enforced female submission are parts of the deal, you’re going to have an abuse problem. Because that’s how abuse thrives. You’re creating the fertile ground for it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway, all of these male-run institutions and governments are sexist, although of course to varying degrees, because consolidating male power is in and of itself sexist. That creates fertile ground for terrible abuses.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Because as far as I can tell, folks can’t really agree on the various rules and requirements of every major religion. So “you should criticize Islam too” isn’t super helpful. But I’m happy to criticize the government of Saudi Arabia, for example, because they are super misogynist
author: JillFilipovic

text: But given that religious texts and traditions are interpreted and reinterpreted, what people pick and choose from them tells us a lot more than the many contradictory things those texts all say. Which is why I find it more valuable to assess religious institutions than religions.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Which doesn’t mean all religious people are sexist or that there aren’t ways to read feminism into religious texts etc etc. But it’s impossible to deny the blatant sexism in these texts too. Turns out old books written by men can be pretty sexist! Who knew.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I have, many times, criticized awful misogyny carried out in the name of Islam by theocratic governments. But “Islam” is not comparable to “the Catholic Church.” It’s comparable to Christianity or Judaism. I’ll be the first to say that most major religious traditions are sexist.
author: JillFilipovic

text: “But what about Islam?” My column wasn’t about Christianity wholesale, or even catholic faith. It was about the institution of the Catholic Church, which is powerful, moneyed, and organized. There isn’t a comparable Muslim institution in the United States. That said...
author: JillFilipovic

text: “But the Catholic Church isn’t sexist because Mary!” If the woman you like the best is only valued for her virginity, her maternity, and birthing a more-important man, you might be sexist. Sexism isn’t just hating all women; it’s also seeing us as secondary players in men’s lives
author: JillFilipovic

text: “But this Pope is progressive!” Nope. He’s more progressive relative to other popes, which surely is great. He also heads an institution which would violate anti-discrimination laws were it not a religious organization. You can’t bar women from power and be called progressive.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And again, if other resources (time, money, planning) are constrained, you will indulge where you can. You will choose time with your kids over rehydrating beans. You will say yes to a candy bar if you can’t say yes to name-brand shoes. Address scarcity and you improve health.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Especially if those kids were like me as a kid, who went vegetarian at 10, or my sister, who refused to eat a meal without meat in it. My mom now likes to cook. When we were kids she hated and resented it. For good reason! Chores suck.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I love to cook. I cook a lot. But I also love having the ability to come home tired and exhausted and look in the fridge and say “fuck it let’s order Thai.” I love that I can have dinner at 7 or at 11. If I had kids? Who also had to eat at a certain hour? Cooking is way less fun.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Also: cooking is a skill. It does not come innate in women. If you never learned how to do it, or don’t enjoy it, that’s another barrier. And cooking as creative expression is (or can be) very different than cooking as necessary fuel for your family.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I have a pressure cooker too. It cost $100 and takes up more counter space that I had in my earlier apartments. Look, I love beans! But that’s not the answer for families who are crunched for money, time and health.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Still in Shanghai! But let me know if you need a place to stay... (email me!)
author: JillFilipovic

text: And I’ll stop tweeting about this shortly, BUT: “just make a big batch of beans, freeze them, and eat them for a week!” is not a healthy and varied diet. Also: food is a pleasure. It’s emotional. Any sane and successful food policy had to address that.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Um, also? Sometimes people are just tired and lazy. If you’re rich you can order takeout from the local organic market. If you’re poor you get McDonald’s. That’s an income and access issue, not an indication that the poor are lazier than the rich.
author: JillFilipovic

text: How long does it take to make beans? (I make my own beans when I can. But it requires time and the ability to plan ahead).
author: JillFilipovic

text: All of which is to say: I am a person who is concerned about how Americans eat. I think we have a national dysfunction when it comes to food. Individuals play a role (a big one). But this is a story about culture, opportunity, access. It’s about how we work. Not just how we eat.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Comfort food - or sweets or fast food or snacks or sugar cereal - is a way to tell your kid “I can give you something special” when most special things are unaffordable and beyond your reach. Great piece on that here:
author: JillFilipovic

text: Food is also comfort and love. I make the least healthy food choices when I’m stressed, exhausted or sad. We all do. For folks who can’t afford relaxing vacations or other indulgences - a yoga class, a massage, new sneakers for your kid - comfort food is an affordable luxury.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Is that the physically healthiest choice? No. Is it emotionally and spiritually healthy? Yes. People, especially parents, who have far less economic privilege than me have to make these calculations day by day and week by week. Address the time crunch and you address health.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not a parent. Nor am I low-income. But when I’m busy or traveling and not able to spend time with my partner, I covet the little time we do have together. Those are the times we go for convenience and eating out - because we are choosing to value connection over vegetables.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Also: time constraints mean you may be choosing between chopping, prepping, cooking and cleaning up after a meal, and helping your kids with their homework, or tucking them in at night and reading a story.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Time matters. And that is what so many people, especially people who are poor or who are wage laborers, don’t have — or their time is not predictable. That is, they may not have consistent work hours / childcare / etc, all of which make it really hard to shop and plan meals.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Food deserts are huge problems. But some interesting studies have shown that food deserts may not be the primary driver of reliance on convenience foods; they may not be the primary reason people don’t eat fresh fruits and vegetables, lean proteins, etc., although they contribute
author: JillFilipovic

text: Those things are not insignificant. Yes, you can cook at home more often, use dried beans purchased in bulk, etc. If you have the ability to plan and the time to shop, prep and cook, eating healthy is accessible for most budgets, and cheaper than fast food.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Seeing so many critiques (and straight-up angry dismissals) of this tweet, many for good reason. To engage it: it’s true that eating healthy does not have to be expensive. It doesn’t have to cost a lot of money. But it often costs time, energy, and comfort.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I always find your work useful! And yes let’s chat. Come to DC :)

text: On the dangers of doxxing: There is a very big difference between revealing the name of an influential pseudonymous or anonymous person and publishing someone's home address.

text: So yes, give women more tools to make reproductive choices. And also give them more opportunities - for education, for fair pay, and for support when they do have children, whenever that is.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And the desire to have kids later is about opportunity and politics. Should birth control and abortion be more widely accessible? Absolutely. Many more women would plan if they could. But many would still choose to have kids young, because in their circumstances, it’s rational.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Those same women are also more likely to carry a pregnancy to term even if they don’t plan to be with the father long-term.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Yes. But because of high incarceration rates and job instability, there are fewer of those men to go around. Also, the traditional gender role thing means many men expect a wife to be subservient, and while women may say they want tradition, in practice that’s less appealing.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Their lives are more stable as a result. They are wealthier. They are less likely to remain trapped in abusive relationships. Their kids are in a better position to succeed. Their marriages will (statistically) last longer. This is all enabled by the ability to plan your family.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And we would recognize that abortion and birth control are key tools to allow women to thrive and chart their own courses. I’ll bet that just about every one of those college-educated women who planned their pregnancies in their 30s used birth control. Many had abortions.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If we actually wanted life to be better for women and for all babies to get a better start, we would ensure access to quality education from the start - exactly what red states cut. We would make college affordable for all (which would mean free for many). We would pay fair wages
author: JillFilipovic

text: If we actually wanted life to be better for mothers and babies (and everyone!), we would even this playing field - not by shaming women who have kids in their 30s (which is what a lot of conservative family scholars do) or by assuming less-educated women make bad choices.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If there’s no career to build & finances will always be precarious, there’s less of a reason to delay childbearing. Of course, the reality is that carrying unplanned pregnancies to term can keep women in poverty. That’s where the traditional roles / anti abortion bit comes in.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If you aren’t going to college and don’t foresee a route to breaking into the middle class, what’s gained by delaying childbirth? Women in my cohort (educated, urban) delay because we’re building our careers & finances and finding the kind of partner we want to be with long term.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Women who have kids earlier are much more likely to live in conservative areas that hew to traditional gender roles. They are likely to be poorer. That’s partly about culture. But it’s also about how political choices constrain women’s opportunities and shape our choices.
author: JillFilipovic

text: The kids born to older mothers have all kinds of advantages: more money, resources, and time. They have a huge leg up. Their mothers also are much more likely to live in progressive cities and value gender equality. Feminist norms, in other words, are good for women and families.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course! I don’t think anyone (reasonable) expects that kids will never cry or have meltdowns or act out. I do think it’s reasonable for a parent to not set a kid loose racing around a restaurant for an hour.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Super interesting: there’s been a huge divergence in age of first birth between women with college degrees and women without. There’s always been a gap, but it’s gotten really wide:
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway look, I know this stuff touched a nerve because judgment of moms in public is absolutely real, and particularly sexist. But serious entitlement is real too, especially at the expense of service workers. And I like to think we can talk about both.
author: JillFilipovic

text: If you want your kid to run around while you eat, ok! Go to a place that has a children’s play area. Win win. But a restaurant isn’t a playground.
author: JillFilipovic

text: You seriously think it’s just fine to bring a child to a restaurant, sit down and eat, let your kid do more or less whatever because you’re tired (including running around the restaurant for 30 minutes), and anyone who objects should shut up and leave or they’re being judgy?
author: JillFilipovic

text: My point is parents can participate in public spaces just like anyone else, without shame. And should! And they mostly do. But that also means behaving like anyone else, and teaching one’s small dining companions to do the same.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Sure. But if your kid is running around a restraint while you eat, who do you think ends up in charge of making sure they aren’t burned by hot food?
author: JillFilipovic

text: In my experience, parents with children are overwhelmingly respectful diners. But the idea that parenthood is stressful so it’s ok to let your kid run around a restaurant and anyone who doesn’t like it can leave is... not respectful.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Otherwise, it’s super entitled. It treats the staff poorly. It disregards the needs of other diners, who perhaps want a few minutes of quiet away from their stressful lives (and perhaps kids!).
author: JillFilipovic

text: I mean... restaurants are shared spaces. The staff is paid to serve food, not care for children. Children running around when waiters are carrying hot food is actually dangerous. If you want your kid to run free while you eat, there are kid-friendly restaurants that cater to that
author: JillFilipovic

text: Maybe! And you should take that beef up with those people.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I’m not saying kids shouldn’t be in public spaces; quite the opposite. I’m saying your waitress isn’t your childcare provider, and neither are other patrons. Bring your kid out! But restaurants aren’t playgrounds. This is common sense.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Part of children learning social norms is teaching them.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Did your spirited child transport themselves to a restaurant or did you bring them there?
author: JillFilipovic

text: That’s exactly what I mean! People sometimes have meltdowns (especially small people). It’s a parent’s job to manage that, not a waitress’s (and not another diner’s). And also, parents should be able to go out to restaurants with or without children.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So much good conversation happening around the toxic motherhood norms in the US. While we’re at it, can we universalize the norm that children can be in most spaces but letting them race around restaurants / shriek incessantly / be supervised by restaurant employees is not ok?

text: We aren’t going to convince him. But if we’re polite, then he will be polite back, and everyone will walk away feeling righteous and satisfied and open-minded and I suppose that’s what is supposed to count.

text: But of course we benefit from being polite about racism. It makes thanksgiving more comfortable. It means we can hew to the fiction that the guy with the confederate flag plates actually cares about “heritage” and is a good-hearted soul.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Throughout American history, African Americans have been doing the naming, and they’ve paid the price. Today’s storied Dr. King, avatar for nonviolence, was hated, demonized, and painted as a violent radical by racist whites. White liberals bear almost no cost for naming racism.
author: JillFilipovic

text: There’s this wonderful fiction that if we’re just polite enough, racists will see the light. White liberals tried that for a 100-plus years. It did not work. Calling racism what it is may not convert racists. But it has the benefit of being honest and holding people accountable.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Also, for the overwhelming majority of american history, racism was dealt with politely, as simply a political issue meriting thoughtful compromise. It did not end racism. Instead, it perpetuated and enables slavery, segregation, and state-sanctioned racist murders and abuses.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Oh good, another article telling us not to call racists “racists.” Let’s stipulate to this: calling someone a racist does not usually convince them to be less racist. But that’s not the only goal of naming racism. For writers, accurate words matter.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Well past time our legal system caught up with this modern reality. There are so few protections and so little recourse for people who are maliciously lied about, and truly insufficient consequences for those who intentionally spread malicious lies (I’ve run into a few On Here).

text: Totally choose your own name! Change it legally, go to court, whatever. But taking your husband’s name upon marriage is not a feminist act. It’s a centuries old act of women’s identities being voided by marriage.

text: I didn’t say you are personally not a feminist. Just that women taking husbands names is unfeminist. It’s ok, we all do unfeminist things! I’m simply saying it’s unhelpful and dishonest to pretend a choice is just a choice made with no social context and no political co sequences
author: JillFilipovic

text: Your name is your name (and by that logic, your father’s name isn’t his name and your husband’s name isn’t his either). Don’t get me wrong, do what you want! I do tons of unfeminist things too, we’re all human. But let’s not act like men have names and women don’t.
author: JillFilipovic

text: So weird, I’m in this same movie. https://twitter.com/jessicavalenti/status/1022471302811201536 …
author: JillFilipovic

text: Of course it happens, but it’s extremely rare (the number of men who change their names upon marriage is so minuscule it’s statistically insignificant).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Also: if you’re a hetero couple, give your kid the mom’s name. No it’s not fair, but neither was several centuries of patriarchy and patriarchal naming traditions. Plus she did all the hard work and will probably continue to do more. Kid gets her name.
author: JillFilipovic

text: and no, it is not the case that “feminism is about choice.” Feminism is about undoing lifetimes of female subjugation. Which doesn’t mean we kick you out if you change your name, but it also doesn’t make marital name-changing feminist. And it does make name-changing anti-feminist
author: JillFilipovic

text: This is why changing your name when you marry isn’t just a “personal choice.” (Note too that men aren’t asked to make any choice at all). It’s a political decision, situated in centuries of male control over women in marriage, and the erasing of married women’s identities.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Because Lyft isn't in Kenya.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anyway, it's a terrible and exploitative business model which results in a terrible and frustrating service, and no one (except Uber's corporate overlords) is happy with it -- not the drivers and not the customers.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And the pay is so little that good taxi drivers aren't going to start driving Ubers. So they put good, reliable, knowledgable drivers out of business, AND they offer an inferior service, AND they criminally under-pay the drivers they do hire (who I can't imagine stay long).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Drivers don't know Nairobi at all and never have any idea where they're going; they expect you to direct them (this is not helpful for tourists). They don't want to use the map, because @Uber pays so little, they (understandably) don't want to pay for data.
author: JillFilipovic

text: I drive myself 90% of the time, and call a great taxi driver 9%; but I end up in ubers when, for example, my car key breaks off in the lock late at night, or when the battery dies and I'm in a rush to get to an appointment. It is almost never a smooth, convenient process.
author: JillFilipovic

text: For example: Drivers CONSTANTLY accept rides and then refuse to come pick you up, but won't cancel the trip. It seems if you cancel, they get the Ksh 150 fee; if they cancel, they don't get it. Since trips themselves cost so little, they are incentivized to accept but not drive.
author: JillFilipovic

text: .@uber @uber_kenya drivers are striking in Nairobi today, demanding better rates. I mostly avoid using Uber here, but when I do, it's almost uniformly terrible - the issues are largely bad driver behavior incentivized by exploitative corporate practices.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And while we’re all talking about rights that aren’t listed in the Constitution nor what the founders intended, here’s a good one: the idea that every American has an individual right to own masses of fireaems.

text: Confidential to scholars from the University of Twitter School of Law: Roe is not the first, nor the only, case to discuss penumbras and emanations, nor the first to discern meaning of rights not directly listed in the constitution. Griswold lists some:

text: Might I recommend reading the 14th Amendment, which is pretty solid for us equal protection fans (the 9th is also pretty good on the question of whether rights must be enumerated in the constitution for Americans to hold them).

text: Anyway, that's where we're about to find ourselves, and you can bet that #prolife activists and politicians don't want to talk about it beyond "end Roe" and "end abortion" (Roe might end; abortion will not). And I wrote all about this for @TIME:
author: JillFilipovic

text: And I'm not sure you can strike down Roe by deciding that a right to privacy doesn't exist, and continue to uphold the many other cases that hinged on the constitutional right to privacy (cases legalizing contraception, some pretty normal consensual sex acts, etc).
author: JillFilipovic

text: So those are basically your two choices: Either you prosecute women who have abortions, or you treat pregnant women like moral and emotional children under the law. That's the #prolife vision.
author: JillFilipovic

text: What they will say is that they want to prosecute the doctors and not women, who are victims. But that doesn't square. If you hire a hitman to kill your four-year-old, no one says you're a victim. (Also, prosecuting doctors for helping desperate women is not great!)
author: JillFilipovic

text: Anti-abortion forces always say they won't prosecute women. This is undermined by the fact that they already prosecute women who self-induce their own abortions. And if abortion is murder and a fetus is a person deserving of state protection, well...
author: JillFilipovic

text: To clarify: The big critique of Roe here is that the court invented a right to privacy. But that right was used earlier to strike down a law barring contraceptive use in Griswold. It was later used to strike down a Texas law outlawing sodomy. It's not just at issue in Roe.
author: JillFilipovic

text:
Some questions here:
1. If you're hoping the court does away with the right to privacy that gave us Roe (abortion), does that mean we get rid of Griswold (contraception) and Lawrence (same-sex intercourse) as well?
2. If abortion is murder, should women face criminal penalties?
author: JillFilipovic

text: We cycle through these conversations so often. What if a man punching his girlfriend were as shocking and usual, and treated with as much seriousness, as a man punching a senator or a famous painting or even just a random stranger on the street?
author: JillFilipovic

text: It sure is real harassment though, which is why I used the word "harassment."
author: JillFilipovic

text: I wish that when women talked about online harassment / street harassment / all the indignities that quickly segue to real threats that come with simply being a woman in public (and virtual) space, we weren't laughed off or met with a serious nod then gently pushed to the side.
author: JillFilipovic

text: And so I am glad that we are finally talking about how every dude who shot up a school / street / club / newspaper had violence against women in his past. That's so important. But also, I wish violence against women was enough for outrage and action in and of itself.
author: JillFilipovic

text: But when it's "just" harassment of women, or violence against women, it's kinda-sorta expected and so not such a big deal, or it's "private" and so not such a big deal (just ask Jeff Sessions why domestic violence victims don't qualify for asylum - private violence, he said).
author: JillFilipovic

text: Writers - and feminist writers in particular - have been sounding the alarm on this for a long time: on "incels," men's rights activists, men who behave in fundamentally aggressive and anti-social ways to women. We've been saying: This is a problem. Please see it.
author: JillFilipovic

text: Here's a fun fact: One troll of a great many who I ignored turned out to be a person who was easily able to track me down in my real life, and indeed showed up and confronted me in person. Later, he was arrested & convicted for making death threats (to a man).
author: JillFilipovic
